document.masterDocTitle: Notes on the genus Neochauliodes from Guangxi, China (Megaloptera: Corydalidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Notes on the genus Neochauliodes from Guangxi, China (Megaloptera: Corydalidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis . Forewings with intercostal area densely spotted at base; hindwings with broad median transverse band. Aedeagus slightly curved to right in ventral view, with middle portion strongly inflated in lateral view.
Description . Forewing length 26–29 mm , hindwing length 22–33 mm .
Head dark, with clypeus pale yellow. Compound eyes brown, ocelli yellow with black inner margin. Antenna black. Mouthparts pale yellow; mandible tip dark.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–17. Genitalia of
Neochauliodes bowringi (McLachlan)
. 14. Male genitalia, lateral view. 15. Aedeagus, ventral view. 16. Male tenth tergum, dorsal view. 17. Female genitalia, lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Thorax dark brown; meso­ and metanotum each with pale brown center stripe. Legs dark with short, dense, brown setae; tarsal claws reddish brown. Wings subhyaline with brown marks; pterostigma pale yellow. Forewing with scattered brown spots; basal intercostal area with spots denser and darker, and with diffuse spots forming bands before and behind pterostigma; median transverse band extending from C to R 4 . Hindwing similarly marked except for basal half entirely hyaline; median transverse band wider, longer, and denser than that on forewing, extending from C to Cu. Veins pale brown except for those on brown marks, which are darker. Rs 5 ­branched with R 2 2 ­branched; 3 crossveins between R 1 and Rs; M 2 ­branched; 1 A 2 ­branched.

Materials examined. 1 ɗ, CHINA : Hunan, Hengnan, 1981 .

Distribution . China (Fujian, Guangxi, Guangdong, Guizhou, Hainan, Hongkong , Hunan, Jiangxi, Shannxi); Vietnam .

Remarks . This species seems to be closely related to
N. orientalis Yang &Yang
from Yunnan in having the basal costal area of the forewings densely marked with dark brown, but can be easily distinguished from it by the broad median transverse band of the hindwing. In
N. orientalis
, the band is rather narrow and shortened.
